By the way, they have been low for 20 years. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Paul Silverstein, Credit Suisse - Analyst [29] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Frank, can you share with us what the regional gross margin was? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- John Chambers, Cisco Systems, Inc. - Chairman & CEO [30] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- That is a nice way of saying I did not answer that part of the question. Let me look it up. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Laura Graves, Cisco Systems, Inc. - Director of Global IR [31] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- We have got -- it is on the slides that are on the website. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Frank Calderoni, Cisco Systems, Inc. - EVP & CFO [32] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- So if you look at it, you mentioned in emerging markets, so the margins went up several points. The current margin right now for Q3 was 64.3%. So the combined margins, products, services as well as financing, and that was up several points, as I said, quarter on quarter. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Paul Silverstein, Credit Suisse - Analyst [33] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- And AsiaPac? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Frank Calderoni, Cisco Systems, Inc. - EVP & CFO [34] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- AsiaPac went from 61.2% to 62.5%, so they improved quarter on quarter. All the other theaters as well. USA and Canada went from 62.2% to 63.7%, and Europe went from 65% to 65.2%, and of course, the overall total 62.4% to 63.9%. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Paul Silverstein, Credit Suisse - Analyst [35] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- John, one related if I might, is your public sector business from a margin perspective any different than your Enterprise in general? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- John Chambers, Cisco Systems, Inc. - Chairman & CEO [36] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- It is better, and we have much larger market share. So in routing and switching in public sector and the developed around the world, we are the number one player by a much higher percentage point well in excess of 70% in switching and well in excess of 80% in routing. The reason is we help them solve the business problems. We do it secure. We do it architecturally, etc. So we get hit disproportionately both on margins and revenue growth when they slow. To answer the indirect part of your question on public sector, we do not think we have a major competitive differentiation here. There is always competitors changing the game there. We are very effective on maintaining the majority of our market share. That does not mean in one area of state and local government (inaudible) rate may not be an issue and on others it may. So we need to think about it in terms of that tone, Paul, for the balance. Sorry, a little bit long on that. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Laura Graves, Cisco Systems, Inc. - Director of Global IR [37] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- That's okay. I'm going to keep us moving to be fair. Next question, operator. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator [38] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Ehud Gelblum, Morgan Stanley. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Ehud Gelblum, Morgan Stanley - Analyst [39] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- First, just a couple of quick clarifications and then a question. The gross margin was strong this quarter. I know you describe the gross margins down next quarter on mix, partially with UCS and partially due to some one-time issues. Frank, if you can just give us a sense as to why gross margin was strong this quarter, and how much of it was from these one-time issues? That would be helpful just to understand that. And a bit of clarification. Flip, as it is now, it's not a discontinued operation. Was it in the numbers for this quarter, and is it in next quarter, or how should we look as to what that revenue did? John, you mentioned in a previous question you mentioned the answer something about the gross margin of the Nexus 7000. Did I hear you say high gross margins? I -- -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- John Chambers, Cisco Systems, Inc. - Chairman & CEO [40] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- No, I said low gross margins and that (multiple speakers) -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Ehud Gelblum, Morgan Stanley - Analyst [41] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- I'm sorry, high teens? Was it really high teens for the gross margins for the 7000, or was that relative to something else? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- John Chambers, Cisco Systems, Inc. - Chairman & CEO [42] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- So let me answer the questions, and we will take them in sequence. Occasionally I speak a little bit fast. Please forgive me for that. And I also want to hear very directly the areas we need to improve on. Switching is clearly one that if you look at seeing that decline, I mean that is one that we need to improve on also. Now to answer the question, the gross margins at the low end 2000 and 3000 are very close, a couple of points below what our original 2000 was. The Nexus 2000 and 5000, which are new, have come up very well over last year, and that is just classic Cisco execution. On the high-end, our 6000 had very good margin. Our Nexus 7000 is below that in the high teens. So I'm just being very open with you for you to be able to do the math on why you see the pressure on margins. We have one product area that has very high margins with the product it is replacing, as well as the classic 2 to 1 leverage point in terms of double or triple the price performance, which means you guys held 2 to 3 times the number to get the same capability. On Flip, Flip was in the results for part of the quarter, but it is out for next quarter. And so in your modeling, that is about 1% of our total business that is gone. So when you think about growth, take 1% out for next quarter in terms of the growth because we will not have revenue on that. The first part of the gross margin mix, Frank? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Frank Calderoni, Cisco Systems, Inc. - EVP & CFO [43] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- So let me just, at a very high level, if you look at it from Q2 to Q3, I would say there are three major categories that I would identify from a margin standpoint. As you know, the margin improvement overall was 1.5 points. About half of that was related to these nonrecurring items. Another portion was related to the consumer, primarily around Flip in the delta quarter on quarter. One had to do with the lower volume as it relates to the performance and exiting the business, and the second has to do with removal of some of the inventory impacts that we had seen in the previous quarter. And then the third piece is a combination of services margin improvement quarter on quarter, as well as some slight improvement in the other base business, which is a combination of some mix, as well as overall margin improvement. So going into Q4, you don't have the nonrecurring and the consumer from a quarter on quarter. It is pretty -- it gets to be a bit more consistent. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator [44] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Brian Modoff, Deutsche Bank. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Brian Modoff, Deutsche Bank - Analyst [45] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- So John, just to be clear, so you're saying that the 7000 gross margin is in the high teens? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- John Chambers, Cisco Systems, Inc. - Chairman & CEO [46] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- No, no. I think -- let me re-word that. What he is saying is -- and he is right. I did a poor job of explaining that. Please forgive me. Gross margins of the 6000 are at the very high level. You all know where they are. Gross margins at the 7000 are below that, let's say, by 18 points to be very specific. And so as you think about the math, that is the delta between the two, and I did a very poor job of saying that. And Brian, thank you for correcting me in a way that the audience clearly understands. Is that your question? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Laura Graves, Cisco Systems, Inc. - Director of Global IR [47] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- You get another question now, Brian. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Brian Modoff, Deutsche Bank - Analyst [48] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- That was a clarification. The question is around going back to switching again. Can you talk about port shipments? How did they do on a year-on-year basis? Revenue is down 9%. How did port shipments do, and can you break it down between datacenter and campus, please? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- John Chambers, Cisco Systems, Inc. - Chairman & CEO [49] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- I'm not sure we have it in that way, Brian. We might need to do it as a follow-up. Let me perhaps give you an idea in terms of the revenues. I think the revenues were down 5% on the -- if I'm remembering right -- let me verify it before I state it -- down 5% in terms of the fix, and as I said earlier, the orders were up about 8% year over year. In terms of the actual port shipment breakout, I don't have it. We ran that analysis when I was looking at share of market. It's a nice way of saying I don't have the data to answer your question. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Laura Graves, Cisco Systems, Inc. - Director of Global IR [50] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Brian, we will follow up with you after the call. We are expecting just preliminary market share data is just coming in now. Full market share will come in over the next couple of weeks. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- John Chambers, Cisco Systems, Inc. - Chairman & CEO [51] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Since I did not answer the question, do you have one more? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Brian Modoff, Deutsche Bank - Analyst [52] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Yes, councils. So you went from five to three. So you are streamlining them, but do you think -- are you contemplating perhaps eliminating them altogether? Do you think more of a direct line management structure might be a better structure for the firm to get more direct accountability to the various divisions? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- John Chambers, Cisco Systems, Inc. - Chairman & CEO [53] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Let me have Gary go through it in just a second, but let me be very explicit. We went from nine councils to three councils, and we went from 42 boards to 15. We moved the decision-making clearly into engineering and into sales for the decisions. We used the councils by customer segments, which are Enterprise, service provider and emerging, and that to connect our strategy, to connect it with our operations. Clear decision-making is back into functional groups, and Gary has just done an amazing job here. So Gary, take it down one more level. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Gary Moore, Cisco Systems, Inc. - EVP & COO [54] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Yes, so I mean at the high level John hit it quick. So to come at it a different way, the key message here is we moved to functional leadership driving the three councils we have left. So Padmasree Warrior, who is one of the co-heads of all of engineering along with Pankaj, the two of them own the number along with in Rob's organization that he announced Nick Adamo a line to Pankaj drive our customer-facing business with service providers globally. They may the decision, and they own the number. So it is not a group thing anymore. That group, that council there said that we can stay close to those customers, collaborate across the different functions that support them, but more importantly get that feedback into engineering from a product point of view, as well as when we talk to you about our service provider business. We have to be aligned and competitive in the service provider business. The same thing in Enterprise. And so Padmasree Warrior and Paul Mountford will co-lead that council, and they both have decision-making responsibility for both sales and engineering. The third council that we left in place is also customer-facing from the point of view, it is our Emerging Countries Council, and that council is again helping to drive the transformation we are doing. We are setting up legal entities. We are doing a lot of work at Cisco to get things done to be able to operate in countries where we have not had the infrastructure. I felt it was important to let that work continue on, and there is a lot of good people that are driving that. So, again, we are holding the country leadership accountable to drive that, but we are giving them a forum to reach into. So elimination of six councils and 31 boards that we did is not the headline here. The headline here is the way we have changed the way that we are operating to drive simplicity and agility into the organization. As John said, we are going to drive our earnings faster than our revenue. This is the way we have to do it. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- John Chambers, Cisco Systems, Inc. - Chairman & CEO [55] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- So simple takeaway in summary. We have simplified our organization and operating model. That is what we just did, and we did it both with engineering, sales and also our services. We are using the Council & Board's purely as how you connect the strategy to the execution, which, by the way, you need architecturally. We also recognize that the strength during one stage of your development, i.e. developing individual products to compete with each other during the 90s becomes your weakness later. Councils & Boards we did not evolve quick enough where we needed to go on that. It allows us to align cost structure. It allows us to make better decisions in terms of who has ownership on divesting of underperforming assets the way we are set up, and bottom line it brings more value to our shareholders. That is what we are really focused on short and long term. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Laura Graves, Cisco Systems, Inc. - Director of Global IR [56] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator, I think we have time for one more question, please. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator [57] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Brian White, Ticonderoga. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Brian White, Ticonderoga - Analyst [58] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Just you talk a lot about UCS. It obviously has pretty strong momentum here. I'm wondering if you could talk a little bit about VCE with the Vblock solution. There is a lot of buzz interop around that. Maybe if we can get some metrics around VCE and Vblock. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- John Chambers, Cisco Systems, Inc. - Chairman & CEO [59] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Got you. I think once again Cisco, along with our partner, EMC and VMware, called a market transition well ahead of what actually has occurred, and you had to. Our movement in the cloud when Padma came here two and half years ago, we did not have a good cloud strategy, and Padma did an amazing job there. So the combination -- and this is why it has to be architectural plays, not only in terms of datacenter of various products, but also within our customers' changing buying behaviors as they begin to see the ability to buy the drink within that, the relationship with VCE is extremely important. We are making very good progress on that, and our pipeline is looking more and more -- I'm not sure what I have. I probably don't have authorization to share that. We have to coordinate with EMC and VMware, but our pipeline looks very good. If I were to just talk federal government alone, we had to move from just traditional routing and switching, etc. We moved quickly to collaboration, and we moved into cloud. And yet we are still seeing the decline, but the pipeline is almost doubling every quarter in terms of large cloud opportunities. And this type of relationship has tremendous power for our group. But, again, it is an architectural play, not pinpoint products. If you are a pinpoint product player, you are going to get commoditized over time or just put into the infrastructure. So good momentum on it. Michael Capellas is doing a very good job of leading that group and creating both the understanding from customers and the integration. And I think and I speak for Joe Tucci and myself and Paul Maritz in saying we are very pleased with where we are on it. Good momentum. I think this is a market -- the question is our peers are now starting to come at it the same way with their own development. So we have got to be able to pull it back together. And Laura is very nicely saying I'm coming up on a time constraint. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Laura Graves, Cisco Systems, Inc. - Director of Global IR [60] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Do you have any closing remarks? -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- John Chambers, Cisco Systems, Inc. - Chairman & CEO [61] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Yes, I do. You know my normal approach would be to talk about all the positives, and there are a lot of areas here. I'm going to focus on the two areas that are problematic for us. And it is important to understand in switching and in public sector, that gives us challenges on our growth number that we have to be able to move faster in terms of organization structure, but also bring expenses not only in line with topline growth, but grow topline growth faster and potentially dramatically faster than you grow expenses. We are going to approach this very simply. First, by simplifying our focus on organization and operating model; secondly, by aligning the cost structure given these transitions that are occurring; third, by divesting or exiting underperforming operations; and fourth, a fanatical approach to delivering value for our shareholders. Our board, our leadership team, our employees are united in this type of approach. We are going to move very decisively in controlling our own destiny. And by the way, how many times have we not in the past? I think while the path this time will clearly be different, every time we have gone through this we emerge as a stronger player. A nice way of saying, if I were a competitor, this is a tough company to bet against whether you are talking switching, routing, data centers, UCS, mobility, video, collaboration overall in terms of the approach. There are areas that we must do different, and the buck stops here. It is my responsibility. I get it. We are going to move rapidly in terms of the direction. And so the takeaway from this call, we want to thank you, especially the shareholders, for your supporting us. We need to really focus on getting you the return both short-term and long-term, and that is our commitment as a leadership team. Well, with that, let me turn it back to you. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator [62] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Thank you, John. We remind our audience that Cisco's next quarterly conference call, which will reflect our fourth-quarter and annual fiscal 2011 results, will be on Wednesday, August 10, 2011, at 1.30 PM Pacific time, 4.30 PM Eastern time. As a reminder, downloadable Q3 FY 11 financial statements are available following this call, including revenue segments by product and geography. Income statements, full GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation information, balance sheets, cash flow statements, can all be found there on the Investor Relations website. Click on Financial Reporting. We would like to remind you that in light of Regulation FD Cisco plans to retain its long-standing policy to not comment on its financial guidance during the quarter unless it is done through an explicit public disclosure. Please contact any member of the Investor Relations team with any follow-up questions from this call. We thank you for your participation and your continued support. This does conclude our call. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Operator [63] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Thank you for participating on today's conference call. If you would like to listen to the call in its entirety, you may call 866-357-4205. For participants dialing from outside the US, please dial 203-369-0122. This concludes today's call. You may disconnect at this time.
